## Project Summary Description

The project aims to introduce fuel-efficient improved cookstoves (ICS), specifically the TLC-CQC Rocket Stove, in Zambia to address environmental and health concerns while promoting sustainable practices. Here is a concise overview of the project:

### 1. Technologies/Measures Implemented
The project focuses on the distribution of fuel-efficient improved cookstoves (ICS), specifically the TLC-CQC Rocket Stove. These stoves are designed to enhance thermal transfer, reduce fuel consumption, combat deforestation, minimize indoor smoke pollution, and decrease the time spent collecting firewood.

### 2. Location
Situated in Zambia, the project is positioned at coordinates 13°08'02.0"S latitude and 27°50'57.6"E longitude, targeting communities in need of sustainable cooking solutions.

### 3. GHG Emission Reductions
By distributing fuel-efficient improved cookstoves, the project anticipates an average annual GHG emission reduction of 6.79 t CO2e per year for each project activity instance. Collectively, the group project activity is projected to achieve a substantial reduction of 1,713,078 t CO2e over the entire crediting period.

### 4. Scenario Prior to Project Implementation
Before the project's initiation, the prevailing scenario involved the ongoing utilization of non-renewable wood fuel (firewood) by the local population to fulfill similar thermal energy requirements that the project cookstoves now address efficiently.

### 5. Estimate of Annual Average and Total Reductions
The project is estimated to yield an annual average emission reduction of 6.79 t CO2e per year for each project activity instance, contributing significantly to the total reduction goal of 1,713,078 t CO2e for the group project activity throughout the crediting period.

This project not only aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but also to enhance the quality of life for communities in Zambia through sustainable and eco-friendly cooking practices.

# Monitoring Plan

## Introduction
The Monitoring Plan details the systematic process and schedule for obtaining, recording, compiling, and analyzing monitored data and parameters as outlined in Section 5.2 (Data and Parameters Monitored). It encompasses methods for measuring, recording, storing, aggregating, collating, and reporting on monitored data and parameters. This document also defines the organizational structure, responsibilities, and competencies of personnel involved in monitoring activities, outlines procedures for internal auditing and QA/QC, addresses handling non-conformances with the validated monitoring plan, and details sampling approaches and QA/QC procedures.

## Methods for Data and Parameter Monitoring
Monitoring methods include activities such as visits to the premises, visual inspections, measurements, interviews with ICS end-users, data collection procedures, distribution and monitoring database, spot checking of ICS, and a sample plan for the monitoring survey. Regular calibration of monitoring equipment will be conducted to ensure data accuracy and reliability.

## Organizational Structure and Responsibilities
The organizational structure involves the Project Coordinator coordinating and managing each project Implementer responsible for managing household data collection. Field personnel will receive training on surveying techniques and will be responsible for conducting periodic audits and surveillance of stoves to ensure data integrity and quality.

## Procedures for Internal Auditing and QA/QC
Internal auditing and QA/QC procedures aim to ensure that field personnel review, understand, and sign the monitoring plan. Documentation of out-of-population cases, refusals, and quality control and assurance strategies addressing non-sampling errors are integral parts of the monitoring process to maintain data accuracy and reliability.

## Handling Non-Conformances with Monitoring Plan
Procedures for handling non-conformances with the validated monitoring plan involve a thorough review, understanding, and signing of the plan. Documentation of out-of-population cases, refusals, and quality control and assurance strategies specifically addressing non-sampling errors will be implemented to maintain the integrity of the monitoring process.

## Sampling Approaches and QA/QC Procedures
Sampling approaches will include Simple Random Sampling for monitored parameters, oversampling to compensate for attrition and non-response, adjusting sample sizes for non-responses, and representative sampling for unbiased and reliable estimates with a 90/10 confidence/precision level. QA/QC procedures will be in place to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the collected data.

## GHG Data Collection and Management System
Line diagrams illustrating the GHG data collection and management system will be included to provide a visual representation of the processes involved in monitoring and managing the data effectively.

By adhering to the outlined processes, procedures, and guidelines within this Monitoring Plan, the monitoring activities will be conducted efficiently and effectively, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the monitored data and parameters.
